<p>A pet management API with these endpoints:</p>
<ul>
<li><strong>POST <code>/pets</code></strong> - Create a new pet</li>
<li><strong>GET <code>/pets</code></strong> - List all pets</li>
<li><strong>GET <code>/pets/:id</code></strong> - Get a specific pet</li>
<li><strong>PUT <code>/pets/:id</code></strong> - Update a pet</li>
<li><strong>DELETE <code>/pets/:id</code></strong> - Delete a pet</li>
</ul>

<h2 class="flex scroll-m-28 flex-row items-center gap-2" id="creating-your-first-endpoint"><a data-card="" href="#creating-your-first-endpoint" class="peer">Creating Your First Endpoint</a><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="24" height="24" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round" class="lucide size-3.5 shrink-0 text-fd-muted-foreground opacity-0 transition-opacity peer-hover:opacity-100" aria-label="Link to section"><path d="M10 13a5 5 0 0 0 7.54.54l3-3a5 5 0 0 0-7.07-7.07l-1.72 1.71"></path><path d="M14 11a5 5 0 0 0-7.54-.54l-3 3a5 5 0 0 0 7.07 7.07l1.71-1.71"></path></svg></h2>
<div class="my-4 flex flex-row gap-2 rounded-lg border border-s-2 bg-fd-card p-3 text-sm text-fd-card-foreground shadow-md border-s-blue-500/50"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="24" height="24" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round" class="lucide size-5 fill-blue-500 text-fd-card"><circle cx="12" cy="12" r="10"></circle><path d="M12 16v-4"></path><path d="M12 8h.01"></path></svg><div class="min-w-0 flex flex-col gap-2 flex-1"><div class="text-fd-muted-foreground prose-no-margin empty:hidden"><p>This tutorial focuses on Motia&#x27;s capabilities to create complete backend system from APIs to Streaming AI agents step-by-step. Here, we&#x27;re showcasing writing APIs with Motia Steps - For data persistence, we use a simple JSON file store in the examples. In a real application, you would use a database like PostgreSQL, MongoDB, or any other data store of your choice. The complete store implementation is available in the <a href="https://github.com/MotiaDev/build-your-first-app/tree/api-endpoints" rel="noreferrer noopener" target="_blank">GitHub repository</a>.</p></div></div></div>
<h3 class="flex scroll-m-28 flex-row items-center gap-2" id="configuration"><a data-card="" href="#configuration" class="peer">Configuration</a><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="24" height="24" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round" class="lucide size-3.5 shrink-0 text-fd-muted-foreground opacity-0 transition-opacity peer-hover:opacity-100" aria-label="Link to section"><path d="M10 13a5 5 0 0 0 7.54.54l3-3a5 5 0 0 0-7.07-7.07l-1.72 1.71"></path><path d="M14 11a5 5 0 0 0-7.54-.54l-3 3a5 5 0 0 0 7.07 7.07l1.71-1.71"></path></svg></h3>
<p>Every API endpoint has two parts:</p>
<p><strong>Config</strong> - Defines when and how the step runs:</p>
<div class="relative overflow-auto prose-no-margin my-6"><table><thead><tr><th>Property</th><th>Description</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td><code>name</code></td><td>Unique identifier</td></tr><tr><td><code>type</code></td><td>Set to <code>&#x27;api&#x27;</code></td></tr><tr><td><code>path</code></td><td>URL path for the endpoint</td></tr><tr><td><code>method</code></td><td>HTTP method (GET, POST, PUT, DELETE)</td></tr></tbody></table></div>
<p><strong>Handler</strong> - The function that executes your business logic.</p>
<div class="my-4 flex flex-row gap-2 rounded-lg border border-s-2 bg-fd-card p-3 text-sm text-fd-card-foreground shadow-md border-s-blue-500/50"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="24" height="24" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round" class="lucide size-5 fill-blue-500 text-fd-card"><circle cx="12" cy="12" r="10"></circle><path d="M12 16v-4"></path><path d="M12 8h.01"></path></svg><div class="min-w-0 flex flex-col gap-2 flex-1"><div class="text-fd-muted-foreground prose-no-margin empty:hidden"><p>View on GitHub:</p><ul>

<p>As you can see in this example, Motia handles routing, validation, and error handling automatically. With just a few lines of code, you&#x27;ve built a complete REST API with:</p>
<ul>
<li><strong>Automatic routing</strong> based on your step configuration</li>
<li><strong>Path parameter extraction</strong> (<code>/pets/:id</code> → <code>req.pathParams.id</code>)</li>
<li><strong>HTTP method handling</strong> (GET, POST, PUT, DELETE)</li>
<li><strong>Response formatting</strong> with proper status codes</li>
<li><strong>Built-in error handling</strong> and validation</li>
</ul>
<p>🎉 <strong>Congratulations!</strong> You&#x27;ve successfully created your first API endpoints with Motia. Your pet store API is now ready to handle all CRUD operations.</p>

<li><strong>Deletion Reaper</strong> - Cron jobs that run daily to clean up soft-deleted records and expired data</li>
</ul>

<p>A pet lifecycle management system that automatically guides pets through their journey at your shelter:</p>
<ul>
<li><strong>Automated Status Transitions</strong> - Pets move through stages automatically when conditions are met</li>
<li><strong>Staff Decision Points</strong> - Critical checkpoints where staff make the calls</li>
<li><strong>Smart Progressions</strong> - Some transitions trigger follow-up actions automatically</li>
<li><strong>Validation Rules</strong> - Prevents invalid status changes to keep data consistent</li>
</ul>

<h2 class="flex scroll-m-28 flex-row items-center gap-2" id="understanding-workflows"><a data-card="" href="#understanding-workflows" class="peer">Understanding Workflows</a><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="24" height="24" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round" class="lucide size-3.5 shrink-0 text-fd-muted-foreground opacity-0 transition-opacity peer-hover:opacity-100" aria-label="Link to section"><path d="M10 13a5 5 0 0 0 7.54.54l3-3a5 5 0 0 0-7.07-7.07l-1.72 1.71"></path><path d="M14 11a5 5 0 0 0-7.54-.54l-3 3a5 5 0 0 0 7.07 7.07l1.71-1.71"></path></svg></h2>
<p>So far, you&#x27;ve built API endpoints that respond to requests and background jobs that handle async tasks. But what about coordinating complex business processes that involve multiple steps and decision points?</p>
<p>That&#x27;s where workflows come in. It&#x27;s the conductor of your system - making sure things happen in the right order, at the right time, and only when it makes sense.</p>
<p>In our pet shelter example, a pet goes through many stages:</p>
<ul>
<li>New arrivals need health checks</li>
<li>Healthy pets become available for adoption</li>
<li>Sick pets need treatment before they&#x27;re ready</li>
<li>Adoption applications require staff approval</li>
</ul>
<p>A workflow manages all these transitions, enforcing the rules and keeping everything consistent.</p>
<hr/>
<h2 class="flex scroll-m-28 flex-row items-center gap-2" id="the-pet-lifecycle-journey"><a data-card="" href="#the-pet-lifecycle-journey" class="peer">The Pet Lifecycle Journey</a><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="24" height="24" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round" class="lucide size-3.5 shrink-0 text-fd-muted-foreground opacity-0 transition-opacity peer-hover:opacity-100" aria-label="Link to section"><path d="M10 13a5 5 0 0 0 7.54.54l3-3a5 5 0 0 0-7.07-7.07l-1.72 1.71"></path><path d="M14 11a5 5 0 0 0-7.54-.54l-3 3a5 5 0 0 0 7.07 7.07l1.71-1.71"></path></svg></h2>
<p>When you create a pet, it starts as <code>new</code>. Once the feeding reminder job completes, it automatically moves to <code>in_quarantine</code>. Staff then checks on it and marks it <code>healthy</code>, which automatically progresses to <code>available</code>. When someone wants to adopt, it goes <code>pending</code>, then finally <code>adopted</code>.</p>
<p>The key here is some transitions happen automatically (like <code>healthy</code> → <code>available</code>), while others need staff approval (like <code>in_quarantine</code> → <code>healthy</code>).</p>
<p><strong>What about sick pets?</strong></p>
<p>If staff finds a pet is <code>ill</code>, it automatically moves to <code>under_treatment</code>. When staff marks it <code>recovered</code>, it chains through automatic transitions: <code>recovered</code> → <code>healthy</code> → <code>available</code>.</p>
<p>This mix of automatic progressions and human decision points is what makes workflows powerful - the system handles the routine stuff while keeping people in control of important calls.</p>

<h3 class="flex scroll-m-28 flex-row items-center gap-2" id="how-the-orchestrator-works"><a data-card="" href="#how-the-orchestrator-works" class="peer">How the Orchestrator Works</a><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="24" height="24" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round" class="lucide size-3.5 shrink-0 text-fd-muted-foreground opacity-0 transition-opacity peer-hover:opacity-100" aria-label="Link to section"><path d="M10 13a5 5 0 0 0 7.54.54l3-3a5 5 0 0 0-7.07-7.07l-1.72 1.71"></path><path d="M14 11a5 5 0 0 0-7.54-.54l-3 3a5 5 0 0 0 7.07 7.07l1.71-1.71"></path></svg></h3>
<p>The orchestrator has three main responsibilities:</p>
<ol>
<li><strong>Validate Transitions</strong> - Ensures pets can only move to valid next statuses</li>
<li><strong>Apply Transitions</strong> - Updates the pet&#x27;s status in the store</li>
<li><strong>Trigger Automatic Progressions</strong> - Some statuses automatically progress to the next stage</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>Key Points:</strong></p>
<ul>
<li><code>emits: []</code> - The orchestrator doesn&#x27;t declare emits because it only manages state internally</li>
<li>JavaScript/Python emit events for workflow tracking (optional pattern)</li>
<li>TypeScript focuses purely on state management</li>
<li>All languages validate transitions using the same <code>TRANSITION_RULES</code></li>
</ul>
<hr/>

<h2 class="flex scroll-m-28 flex-row items-center gap-2" id="whats-next"><a data-card="" href="#whats-next" class="peer">What&#x27;s Next?</a><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="24" height="24" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round" class="lucide size-3.5 shrink-0 text-fd-muted-foreground opacity-0 transition-opacity peer-hover:opacity-100" aria-label="Link to section"><path d="M10 13a5 5 0 0 0 7.54.54l3-3a5 5 0 0 0-7.07-7.07l-1.72 1.71"></path><path d="M14 11a5 5 0 0 0-7.54-.54l-3 3a5 5 0 0 0 7.07 7.07l1.71-1.71"></path></svg></h2>
<p>Your pet shelter now has a complete backend system with workflow orchestration! But what about decisions that aren&#x27;t black and white? Should this pet&#x27;s symptoms require treatment?</p>
<p>In the next guide, we&#x27;ll add <strong>Agentic Workflows</strong> that make intelligent decisions within your workflows:</p>
<ul>
<li><strong>Health Review Agentic Step</strong> - Analyzes symptoms and decides if treatment is needed</li>
<li><strong>Adoption Review Agentic Step</strong> - Assesses if pets are ready for adoption</li>
<li><strong>AI Profile Enrichment</strong> - Automatically generates engaging pet profiles</li>
<li><strong>Agentic Decision Making</strong> - AI that chooses which workflow path to take</li>
</ul>

Motia automatically discovers and registers any file following the naming pattern from both directories.</p></div></div></div>
<div class="my-4 flex flex-row gap-2 rounded-lg border border-s-2 bg-fd-card p-3 text-sm text-fd-card-foreground shadow-md border-s-blue-500/50"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="24" height="24" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round" class="lucide size-5 fill-blue-500 text-fd-card"><circle cx="12" cy="12" r="10"></circle><path d="M12 16v-4"></path><path d="M12 8h.01"></path></svg><div class="min-w-0 flex flex-col gap-2 flex-1"><div class="text-fd-muted-foreground prose-no-margin empty:hidden"><strong>Location and nesting rules</strong><ul>
<li>Both the <code>steps/</code> and <code>src/</code> directories are supported at the <em>project root</em> (e.g., <code>my-motia-project/steps</code> or <code>my-motia-project/src</code>).</li>
<li>You can freely nest steps in subfolders under either directory (e.g., <code>steps/aaa/a1.step.ts</code>, <code>src/bbb/ccc/c1_step.py</code>).</li>
<li>Discovery is recursive inside both directories, so deeper folder structures for large apps are supported.</li>
<li>You can use either <code>steps/</code>, <code>src/</code>, or both directories in your project.</li>
</ul></div></div></div>
<h2 class="flex scroll-m-28 flex-row items-center gap-2" id="automatic-step-discovery"><a data-card="" href="#automatic-step-discovery" class="peer">Automatic Step Discovery</a><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="24" height="24" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round" class="lucide size-3.5 shrink-0 text-fd-muted-foreground opacity-0 transition-opacity peer-hover:opacity-100" aria-label="Link to section"><path d="M10 13a5 5 0 0 0 7.54.54l3-3a5 5 0 0 0-7.07-7.07l-1.72 1.71"></path><path d="M14 11a5 5 0 0 0-7.54-.54l-3 3a5 5 0 0 0 7.07 7.07l1.71-1.71"></path></svg></h2>
<div class="my-4 flex flex-row gap-2 rounded-lg border border-s-2 bg-fd-card p-3 text-sm text-fd-card-foreground shadow-md"><div class="min-w-0 flex flex-col gap-2 flex-1"><div class="text-fd-muted-foreground prose-no-margin empty:hidden"><p><strong>Key Concept: Automatic Discovery</strong></p><p>Motia will automatically discover and register <strong>any file</strong> that follows the <code>.step.</code> naming pattern as a workflow step. You don&#x27;t need to manually register steps - just create a file with the right naming pattern and Motia will find it.</p></div></div></div>
<h3 class="flex scroll-m-28 flex-row items-center gap-2" id="discovery-rules"><a data-card="" href="#discovery-rules" class="peer">Discovery Rules</a><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="24" height="24" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round" class="lucide size-3.5 shrink-0 text-fd-muted-foreground opacity-0 transition-opacity peer-hover:opacity-100" aria-label="Link to section"><path d="M10 13a5 5 0 0 0 7.54.54l3-3a5 5 0 0 0-7.07-7.07l-1.72 1.71"></path><path d="M14 11a5 5 0 0 0-7.54-.54l-3 3a5 5 0 0 0 7.07 7.07l1.71-1.71"></path></svg></h3>
<p>Motia scans your <code>steps/</code> and <code>src/</code> directories and automatically registers files as steps based on these rules:</p>
<ol>
<li><strong>File must contain <code>.step.</code> or <code>_step.</code> in the filename</strong> (e.g., <code>my-task.step.ts</code>, <code>my_task_step.py</code>)</li>
<li><strong>File must export a <code>config</code> object</strong> defining the step configuration</li>
<li><strong>File must export a <code>handler</code> function</strong> containing the step logic</li>
<li><strong>File extension determines the runtime</strong> (<code>.ts</code> = TypeScript, <code>.py</code> = Python, <code>.js</code> = JavaScript)</li>
</ol>
<p>When you run <code>motia dev</code>, Motia will:</p>
<ul>
<li>Scan both the <code>steps/</code> and <code>src/</code> directories recursively</li>
<li>Find all files matching <code>*.step.*</code> in both directories</li>
<li>Parse their <code>config</code> exports to understand step types and connections</li>
<li>Register them in the workflow engine</li>
<li>Make them available in the Workbench</li>
</ul>
<h2 class="flex scroll-m-28 flex-row items-center gap-2" id="file-naming-convention"><a data-card="" href="#file-naming-convention" class="peer">File Naming Convention</a><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="24" height="24" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round" class="lucide size-3.5 shrink-0 text-fd-muted-foreground opacity-0 transition-opacity peer-hover:opacity-100" aria-label="Link to section"><path d="M10 13a5 5 0 0 0 7.54.54l3-3a5 5 0 0 0-7.07-7.07l-1.72 1.71"></path><path d="M14 11a5 5 0 0 0-7.54-.54l-3 3a5 5 0 0 0 7.07 7.07l1.71-1.71"></path></svg></h2>
<p>Motia uses this specific pattern for automatic step discovery:</p>

<h2 class="flex scroll-m-28 flex-row items-center gap-2" id="how-it-works"><a data-card="" href="#how-it-works" class="peer">How It Works</a><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="24" height="24" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round" class="lucide size-3.5 shrink-0 text-fd-muted-foreground opacity-0 transition-opacity peer-hover:opacity-100" aria-label="Link to section"><path d="M10 13a5 5 0 0 0 7.54.54l3-3a5 5 0 0 0-7.07-7.07l-1.72 1.71"></path><path d="M14 11a5 5 0 0 0-7.54-.54l-3 3a5 5 0 0 0 7.07 7.07l1.71-1.71"></path></svg></h2>
<p>State organizes data into <strong>groups</strong>. Each group can hold multiple items with unique keys.</p>
<p>Think of it like folders and files:</p>
<ul>
<li><strong>groupId</strong> = A folder name (like <code>orders</code>, <code>users</code>, <code>cache</code>)</li>
<li><strong>key</strong> = A file name inside that folder</li>
<li><strong>value</strong> = The actual data</li>
</ul>

<hr/>
<h2 class="flex scroll-m-28 flex-row items-center gap-2" id="when-to-use-state"><a data-card="" href="#when-to-use-state" class="peer">When to Use State</a><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="24" height="24" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round" class="lucide size-3.5 shrink-0 text-fd-muted-foreground opacity-0 transition-opacity peer-hover:opacity-100" aria-label="Link to section"><path d="M10 13a5 5 0 0 0 7.54.54l3-3a5 5 0 0 0-7.07-7.07l-1.72 1.71"></path><path d="M14 11a5 5 0 0 0-7.54-.54l-3 3a5 5 0 0 0 7.07 7.07l1.71-1.71"></path></svg></h2>
<p><strong>✅ Good use cases:</strong></p>
<ul>
<li><strong>Temporary workflow data</strong> - Data that&#x27;s only needed during a flow execution</li>
<li><strong>API response caching</strong> - Cache expensive API calls that don&#x27;t change often</li>
<li><strong>Sharing data between Steps</strong> - Pass data between Steps without emitting it in events</li>
<li><strong>Building up results</strong> - Accumulate data across multiple Steps</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>❌ Better alternatives:</strong></p>
<ul>
<li><strong>Persistent user data</strong> - Use a database like Postgres or MongoDB</li>
<li><strong>File storage</strong> - Use S3 or similar for images, PDFs, documents</li>
<li><strong>Real-time updates</strong> - Use Motia Streams for live data to clients</li>
<li><strong>Large datasets</strong> - Use a proper database, not state</li>
</ul>
<hr/>
<h3 class="flex scroll-m-28 flex-row items-center gap-2" id="state-adapters"><a data-card="" href="#state-adapters" class="peer">State Adapters</a><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="24" height="24" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round" class="lucide size-3.5 shrink-0 text-fd-muted-foreground opacity-0 transition-opacity peer-hover:opacity-100" aria-label="Link to section"><path d="M10 13a5 5 0 0 0 7.54.54l3-3a5 5 0 0 0-7.07-7.07l-1.72 1.71"></path><path d="M14 11a5 5 0 0 0-7.54-.54l-3 3a5 5 0 0 0 7.07 7.07l1.71-1.71"></path></svg></h3>
<p>State adapters control where and how state is stored. Motia provides default adapters that work out of the box, and distributed adapters for production deployments.</p>
<h4 class="flex scroll-m-28 flex-row items-center gap-2" id="default-adapter-file-storage"><a data-card="" href="#default-adapter-file-storage" class="peer">Default Adapter (File Storage)</a><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="24" height="24" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round" class="lucide size-3.5 shrink-0 text-fd-muted-foreground opacity-0 transition-opacity peer-hover:opacity-100" aria-label="Link to section"><path d="M10 13a5 5 0 0 0 7.54.54l3-3a5 5 0 0 0-7.07-7.07l-1.72 1.71"></path><path d="M14 11a5 5 0 0 0-7.54-.54l-3 3a5 5 0 0 0 7.07 7.07l1.71-1.71"></path></svg></h4>
<p>No setup needed. State goes to <code>.motia/motia.state.json</code>.</p>

<h2 class="flex scroll-m-28 flex-row items-center gap-2" id="remember"><a data-card="" href="[def2]" class="peer">Remember</a><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="24" height="24" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round" class="lucide size-3.5 shrink-0 text-fd-muted-foreground opacity-0 transition-opacity peer-hover:opacity-100" aria-label="Link to section"><path d="M10 13a5 5 0 0 0 7.54.54l3-3a5 5 0 0 0-7.07-7.07l-1.72 1.71"></path><path d="M14 11a5 5 0 0 0-7.54-.54l-3 3a5 5 0 0 0 7.07 7.07l1.71-1.71"></path></svg></h2>
<ul>
<li>Organize data using <strong>groupId</strong> (like <code>orders</code>, <code>users</code>, <code>cache</code>)</li>
<li>Each item needs a unique <strong>key</strong> within its groupId</li>
<li>Use <code>getGroup(groupId)</code> to retrieve all items in a group</li>
<li>State works the same across TypeScript, Python, and JavaScript</li>
<li>Clean up state when you&#x27;re done with it</li>
<li>Use databases for permanent data, state for temporary workflow data</li>
